awd_titl_txt: MRI-R2 Consortium: Development of Improved Instrumentation for the VERITAS Gamma-Ray Observatory
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This MRI-R2 grant supported the purchase and installation of hardware to upgrade the performance and sensitivity of the VERITAS gamma-ray observatory.  The VERITAS Observatory, located at the F.L. Whipple Observatory (Amado, AZ) employs an array of four 12-meter diameter optical reflectors to observe sources of Very High Energy (VHE) gamma-rays from astrophysical sources such as supernova remnants, neutron stars, and black holes.  

The VERITAS upgrade included several components, including installation of higher efficiency light sensors in the VERITAS cameras, installation of a higher speed, programmable pattern trigger in each telescope, and a higher speed, fail-safe (redundant) optical fiber Ethernet network.  The fiber optic network was installed in summer 2010; the high speed triggering system was installed in  summer 2011, and the camera upgrade was installed in 2012. 

The attached figures demonstrate some of the performance improvement of the VERITAS observatory after the upgrade. The cameras demonstrate a 40% improvement in detected light based upon using atmospheric `muon' rungs, which provide a standard calibration light source. The 2.5x improvement in the telescope trigger rate indicates the observatory is detecting a substantially larger number of cosmic-rays and gamma-ray each minute. The 2 dimensional sky-plot  of VER 0521+211 shows a ~50% improvement in the significance of source detection after this MRI-R2 upgrade. This MRI-R@ funded upgrade of the VERITAS Observatory has made VERITAS the most sensitive VHE observatory in the northern hemisphere. 

The upgraded camera and electronics has enabled the VERITAS Observatory to use shorter observations to detect the sources at the same emission level; this is important because VERITAS can only view a small fraction of the night sky, and so this allows the observatory to look a more sources each evening. In addition, it has allowed VERITAS to detect fainter sources than previously possible, and extend the observations of gamma-ray sources to lower gamma-ray energies. These low energy gamma-rays probe the most distant extragalactic sources of high energy gamma-rays. in 2012-2013, the upgraded cameras allowed detection of several weak extragalactic gamma-ray sources that would not have been detectable using the older, less efficient cameras 

The VERITAS Observatory upgrade involved 22 undergraduate students, 9 graduate students and 6 post-doctoral research associates in the construction, test, and commissioning of the VERITAS upgrade components. The upgraded camera has allowed VERITAS to become a key instrument in joint observation campaigns in the radio, optical, X-ray and low energy gamma-ray frequency bands. In 2013, the VERITAS instrument has added joint research program established joint Guest investigator programs with the FERMI gamma-ray satellite, allowing use of the VERITAS telescope capabilities to the general astronomical community.  The VERITAS upgrade was also the first large-scale deployment of high-sensitivity `photomultiplier tube' light sensors.  this manufacturing and testing experience improves the feasibility of  using of these light sensors in medical imaging diagnostic applications, such as CAT scan and PET scan techniques, at lower radiation exposure levels.
